DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the safety and oncological feasibility of robot-assisted surgery for mid/low rectal carcinoma compared with laparoscopic surgery.
DOC.brief_title: Robot-assisted Versus Laparoscopic Surgery for Mid/Low Rectal Cancer
DOC.criteria: histologically proven rectal adenocarcinoma inferior edge of the tumor located within 12 cm from the dentate line as determined by rigid rectoscopy no evidence of distant metastases tumor assessed as cT1T3 by ultrasound colonoscopy and/or pelvic MRI, or ycT1T3 after preoperative neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy no other malignancies in medical history except adequately treated basocellular carcinoma of the skin or in situ carcinoma of the cervix uteri suitable for both robotassisted and laparoscopic surgery informed consent Tumors assessed as cT1N0 and suitable for local excision signs of acute intestinal obstruction, bleeding or perforation needing emergency surgery more than one colorectal tumor Familial Adenomatosis Polyposis, Lynch Syndrome, acute inflammatory bowel disease scheduled need for other synchronous colon surgery absolute contraindications to general anesthesia or prolonged pneumoperitoneum (ASA class > III) pregnancy or lactation
